docs.lead_paragraph: Update | 9/19/09 10:10 p.m. Kara Lynn, who was featured in a Times article because she was using an iPhone for text-to-speech service, offers her own comment about the technological curve.

headline.main: Text-to-Speech Technology Reaches an Inflection Point

docs.abstract: A flood of new devices and software has made text-to-speech technology cheaper and more accessible to those with speech impairments.
docs.snippet: A flood of new devices and software has made text-to-speech technology cheaper and more accessible to those with speech impairments.

docs.lead_paragraph: So, on the morning after the release of the hugely anticipated proposal by Senator Max Baucus, the Senate Finance Committee chairman, members of Congress still disagree about the best way to fix the American health care system. Don't all faint at once.

headline.main: And Now, the Many Exhilarating Steps to Completing a Senate Health Bill

docs.abstract: The Finance Committee's amendment swap-meet will begin to make clear exactly who, on both sides, is serious about getting health care legislation accomplished this year -- and exactly how they propose to do it.
docs.snippet: The Finance Committee's amendment swap-meet will begin to make clear exactly who, on both sides, is serious about getting health care legislation accomplished this year -- and exactly how they propose to do it.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Senate Finance Committee is poised to begin voting next week on the health care legislation unveiled by the committee's chairman, Senator Max Baucus, of Montana.
docs.abstract: Health care remains in the foreground today, as lawmakers pore over the details of the latest bill and the president travels to a health care rally in Maryland.
docs.snippet: Health care remains in the foreground today, as lawmakers pore over the details of the latest bill and the president travels to a health care rally in Maryland.

docs.lead_paragraph: RISHER--Edward H., M.D., 85 years. Died in Manhattan September 15, 2009 after a short illness, surrounded by his family, his loving wife, Lorrie, of 57 years, his children Mary Jo Foley (Stephen), Edward Jr. (Ariadna), Peter and Elise (Andrew Lavallee). In addition he leaves his grandchildren Nicholas and Benjamin Foley, Edward P. Risher, Lucia, Serafina and Delia Lavallee and his brothers Watson and Fred. Dr. Risher retired as Vice President of Employees' Health at New York Life Insurance Company. Memorial gathering will be held on Friday, September 18, 2pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St.
